Regina, 10th Nov., 1886.

To the Electors of the District of
Saskatchewan.
As the Hon. David Laird, ex-Governor
of the Northwest Territories, has been appointed
as Secretary of the Liberal nomination for
the representation of the District of Saskatchewan
in the House of Commons, it becomes necessary for his friends to take immediate
steps to secure his election. It is proposed to hold a meeting of those who are favorable
to his nomination at the residence of Mr. T. O'Leary, store No. 1, Monday,
Dec. 9th, at 2 p.m. All interested parties are invited to attend.

ARTHUR L. SEFTON.

TELEGRAPIIC.
(By Special Telegraph.)
The original stockholders of the North-
west Central have commenced suit against
President Beatty, M. P., to force him to
give back a part of the sum held by him in trust for some one else, but he
refuses to surrender.

The divorce case of Lady Colin Campbell
is now being heard in the courtroom of the day. Damaging evidence against
the lady herself is lacking. The
party of Argyle and her husband are
father and son, and the defendant, she
witnesses.

Shortly after the mines entered into
negotiations with the owner of the
Cory Logan Gallery, Wil-
kensburg, Pa., this morning an explosion
of gas took place between 20 and 30
minutes after breakfast and breakfast
time, but nothing serious was revealed.
The explosion was caused by allowing a
gas to accumulate at the bottom of the shaft
contrary to orders, and when the men
entered with their lamps an explosion
immediately followed.

The British Parliament will meet on
January 2nd.

John Dillon has been summoned to ap-
pear and show cause why criminal in
formation should not be sworn against
him. He has been charged with encouraging tenants to follow the example of
those on the Clan Richard estate in the
county of Galway. Dillon, in the
course of his remarks, had stated that
tenants should be encouraged to evict rather than pay rent as the best
means for bringing owners of lands
into line. He was arrested at Woodland, October 18th. Later
reports from Ireland show serious com-
plaints and trouble cannot be pre-
vented.

The Ottawa Government have com-
pleted arrangements by which the
North-West Mounted Police force will be obtained in the
Dominion. The extensive contracts
given to the force may be expected to
have been satisfactorily filled and
a new sense of uniformity in being
maintained.

George Hamelletti and A. Calley, of
Woodland, went through the rapids and
whirled this afternoon in the most
dangerous manner. They were in the rapids and whirled
five minutes and were taken out of the
rapids by the police boat below the
whirlpool. They were quite exhausted, but
are now in better condition.

The snowstorm has been made the winter port of
Prince Albert.

Nicholas Macdonald secured the nomi-
nation for Western Assiniboia for the
Conservative Members of Parliament last Monday.

Two clerks were buried at Whistle
Stop, Tuesday, victims of almost
being burned, with a loss of a million
dollars and two lives.

Officers of the Marine Depart-
ment state that the steamer, which swept
all the lakes on the 17th and 18th ultimo,
were terribly disastrous. Thirty-two
persons were killed and three vessels
worth $25,000 were wrecked.

Nine youths have been sentenced to
death for committing an outrage on
a 15-year-old servant girl at Sydney, N.S.W.

Martin Fournier, of Ringling, has
been arrested with the order of
detention of the Department of the Interior lately. He
proposed to remove his stock from the
Province of Quebec, and bring $400,000 worth of cattle
across the border with the Government
arrangements made with the Govern-
ment.

The commission in Manitoba took
place yesterday. Wilson retired from
the North West having leaving the field
Goodwin and Harvey. Lawrence was
elected by acclamation for St. Boniface.

Gathered by our Reporters.

R. G. Conington, plasterer, who has been
working on the sidewalks all summer.
Acting Mayor Beal visited St. Ann's
Convent yesterday, and was much pleased
to see the rapid advancement the
building has made in its studies since
last year.

Chas. Waddell, who has been the east
end fireman on Tuesday last, but the
unmistakable of the neighbors have
prevented serious results, part of the roof
being blown away.

Mr. A. C. Reid succeeded Mr.
Swanson on Wednesday evening last, on
the occasion of the arrival home of Mrs.
Swanson, who, as you know, has promised the band
a handsome present.

A Liberal Association has been formed
in Prince Albert, of which John Stewart
is President, Wm. McLeod, Vice-Presi-
dent, Dr. Porter 2nd Vice-President, H.
W. Newlands Treasurer, and Arthur L.
Sefton Secretary.

Ladies, Gentlemen and Boys Shaking
Books cheap—Monday, Tuesday, Thursday
and Friday, Saturday and Sunday, and Friday
Shaking—Tuesday, Wednesday, and Saturday nights,
and Wednesday and Saturday afternoons.

The Bishop has been consecrated by
the clergy of the diocese of St.
Albert as delegate of the General Chapter
of the Roman Catholic Church, held in
Rome last November. He left St. Albert
for Rome on the 10th of last month, and
will arrive there about the end of this
month, and spend the winter there with his
father, whom he has not seen for a quarter
of a century. His Lordship Bishop Gran-
ville has been appointed Delegate for Albert
for the United States with Father La
combe, where he will spend a couple of
months. His absence will be preceded
to France and Rome.

On Tuesday evening last a genuine
surprise party visited the house of Miss
Agnew. The ladies assembled there for
their departure to visit friends in
Oregon and California. The evening
was spent in pleasant conversation and
partaking of refreshments kindly provided by the hostess.

Miss Baker returned home today, but Miss
Laura Prichard and Miss Anna McTag-
gart stood up before her and read an ad-
dress on behalf of her namesakes, ex-
pressing their sympathy and regret at
her departure from Prince Albert, and wishing her
pleasant journey and a safe return, and
promising her well wishes and companionship
over forty-five dollars. Miss Baker re-
plied briefly but feelingly. Speeches were
made by Rev. Mr. Campbell and Miss Jane, who spoke in very good
English.

The following resolutions were passed at
a large and representative meeting of
residents of the parishes around Batchelor,
held under the presidency of Mr. Pierre
Caron, on Nov. 11th, in Batchelor, with
the object of calling into consideration
certain letters signed by Philip Grant,
secretary to the late Louis Riel, and
published in the "Montreal Leader and
Canadian Recorder." "That the con-
tent of these letters do not meet the
mind of the vast majority. That if
such statements are now circulated through the public press the aforementioned
party will be held responsible for their
responsibility for their contents. That the
Métis, under the present circumstances
are not bound by any agreement, nor
belong to any party, desire to obtain
from any party, and that the said
party must consider this occasion to make
their most sincere apologies to all those
in, without distinction of party, have
sympathy with them in their misfor-
tunes."

FRIDAY, DEC. 3, 1886.

THE LIQUOR QUESTION.

Mr. Terriff's motion in the Northwest Council on the 19th last: "'That the production, sale, manufacture, transportation, or use should not be allowed in the Northwest Territories until a majority of the people who live in those regions by popular vote, that the Northwest Prohibition Act be amended so as to prevent the sale of all liquor excepting such as their voters may allow, but that permits be issued only for medicinal and chemical purposes,' provoked a wide edebate, and demonstrated the fact that there is a great difference between the true Christian and the hypocrite—it would be easy to fit the latter. Mr. Terriff is a man of honour—a friend of the movement; and as a friend of the movement has a perfect knowledge of all that is best in it, most people believe that were prohibition possible and in keeping with the first principles of Christian life, as they are taught in the best schools, then that it could be brought about in the shortest possible time, and that it would bring about the greatest good. But perhaps the most important thing is that it is not merely a question of right and wrong—but it is also a question of the welfare of the people. 

EDITORIAL NOTES.

Miss Horne has at last found a safe resting-place in Prince Albert. For too long we have been deprived of her services and her sympathy. We are glad to see her back—glad to have her back. 

North West Council.

Mr. Pesley presented a petition from the Hon. and council of Qu'Appelle, asking the Council to ratify a resolution on the Peace River, south from Banff and Mt. Macdonald and Qu'Appelle. The petition was received. 

Messrs. Conacher and Philpott have been elected members of the North-West Council. They will fill vacancies caused by the death of Messrs. Stone and Miller. 

The Governor laid on the table the report of the Judicial Committee. It recaps that the judges of H. Inwood Stone are not granted; that Mr. Hultchist, on Tuesday, May 1st, received $200 to purchase a canoe; that Mr. Eagleson has received $30; and that Mr. Henry has received $300 towards his expenses. 

Various matters connected with the administration of the laws were discussed and decided. 

The following matters came before the courts:-

- A man who had been charged with the crime of forgery was found guilty.
- A woman who had been charged with the crime of theft was found guilty.
- A man who had been charged with the crime of assault was found guilty.

The courts were very busy and the officials were kept very busy.
